content.webTitle: ‘Don’t focus on prestige’: students’ tips for choosing the right university

fields.headline: ‘Don’t focus on prestige’: students’ tips for choosing the right university
fields.bodyText: The sheer volume of information and advice about university can be so overwhelming that it’s difficult to know what to base your decision on. We asked 11 current students what they wish they’d known before making their choices. Keep an open mind “Don’t feel obliged to go the conventional route. You don’t have to go to university at 18. You don’t have to just study one subject – multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary options are great.” Explore your options “I wish I’d known that there were more options available than university. That not wanting to go to university didn’t make me less intelligent. Despite not going to university, I’m still in a better position than some of my peers who did go to one.” It’s not just about lectures “Look at the things the university does to support students, what services there are, and what the student union is like. The stuff outside the classroom is as important as what happens in it, and is the stuff that keeps you going when things gets tough.” Don’t be blinded by reputation “Don’t focus on prestige. (Prestige is no guarantee of teaching quality!) Talk to existing students.” Take a good look around “Visit on a non-open day. As someone coming from overseas, I wasn’t able to make open days. But I felt I had a better read on the unis I visited than those who went on the official open days.” Research every detail “Look into the content of the course. It may seem obvious, but one psychology degree is not the same as another ... looking at the research topics of the lecturers is often a good indicator. Oh, and think about how you will afford to get home if you are going to choose a uni in the deepest depths of north Wales ...” Money isn’t everything “Try to look beyond the potential pay cheque at the end of it. Chemical engineers can get paid an absolute mint, but if you aren’t passionate about the subject, you will hate every minute of your degree and you will not want a job in that field.” You don’t have to live in halls “Living away from home is not a choice for some and I was worried I would miss out on the university experience, only getting the ‘boring’ bits. And it’s true, I never lived the student life. But I got to stay at home with a proper clean kitchen, have the students’ night out when I wanted to, and have the break when needed.” Put your passions first “Ensure you choose a course you are genuinely interested in – and a career that requires you to have a degree in the field of your choice, otherwise it is a rather expensive piece of paper. Choose the course, rather than the city with the best nightlife. Beer tastes the same anywhere.” Weigh up your costs “The cost of living can be extortionate in some cities. There’s a huge difference in cost to live in halls at different universities and standards can be grim at the popular unis. I think students get swayed by popularity and where is considered cool to go, but it doesn’t equate to value for money.” Take your time “Do not stress out and do not pick last-minute or in a hurry. There is time. Uni has been one of the best experiences of my life. I waited four extra years to go and I think I gained more from it. You will not enjoy it if you’re not ready or have not made an informed decision. Have fun, and look forward to September!” Get your Guardian University Guide 2020 print supplement free with Saturday’s Guardian 8 June
